verse:
अहमात्मा गुडाकेश सर्वभूताशयस्थित: |
अहमादिश्च मध्यं च भूतानामन्त एव च || 20||
transliteration: aham ātmā guḍākeśha sarva-bhūtāśhaya-sthitaḥaham ādiśh cha madhyaṁ cha bhūtānām anta eva cha
word meanings: aham—I; ātmā—soul; guḍākeśha—Arjun, the conqueror of sleep; sarva-bhūta—of all living entities; āśhaya-sthitaḥ—seated in the heart; aham—I; ādiḥ—the beginning; cha—and; madhyam—middle; cha—and; bhūtānām—of all beings; antaḥ—end; eva—even; cha—also
translation:
BG 10.20:
                            O Arjun, I am seated in the heart of all living entities. I am the beginning, middle, and end of all beings.
commentary: Shree Krishna declares that he is not far from the soul—in fact he is closer than the closest. The ātmā or eternal soul is enthroned in the etheric heart of all living beings. The Vedas state: ya ātmani tiṣhṭhati [v21] “God is seated within our soul.” Seated inside, he grants the power of consciousness and eternality to the soul. If he were to subtract his power, our soul itself would become insentient and perish. We souls are thus eternal and sentient, not by our own power, but because the supremely sentient and eternal God is seated within, and is granting his powers to us. Hence, Shree Krishna declares that he is situated in the heart of all living beings.Our soul is the body of God, who is the Soul of our soul. The Bhāgavatam states:harirhi sākṣhādbhagavān śharīriṇāmātmā jhaṣhāṇāmiva toyamīpsitam(5.18.13)[v22]“God is the ātmā of the ātmā (Soul of the soul) of all living beings.” In the Bhāgavatam again, when Shukadev described how the gopīs used to leave their own children to go and see baby Shree Krishna, Parikshit asked him how this was possible:brahman parodbhave kṛiṣhṇe iyān premā kathaṁ bhavet(10.14.49)[v23]“O Brahmin, all mothers are attached to their own children. How did the gopīs develop such intense attachment to Shree Krishna, which they did not even feel toward their own child?” Shukadev replied:kṛiṣhṇamenamavehi tvamātmānamakhilātmanām(Bhāgavatam 10.14.55)[v24]“Please understand that Lord Krishna is the Supreme Soul of all living beings in the universe. For the benefit of humankind, he has appeared in a human form by his Yogmaya power.”Shree Krishna further states that he is the beginning, middle, and end of all living beings. They have emanated from him, and so he is their beginning. All life that exists in creation is sustained by his energy, and so he is the middle. And those who attain liberation go to his divine abode to live eternally with him. Hence, God is also the end of all living beings. Amongst the various definitions of God given by the Vedas, one of them is:yato vā imāni bhūtāni jāyante yena jātāni jīvanti, yatprayantyabhisaṁviśhanti(Taittirīya Upaniṣhad 3.1.1)[v25]“God is he from whom all living beings have emanated; God is he within whom all living beings are situated; God is he into whom all living beings shall unite.”
new_commentary: In the Bhagavad Gita, Shree Krishna reveals that he is not distant from the soul but rather closer than the closest. He resides within the eternal soul and grants consciousness and eternal power to it. Without his presence, the soul would become lifeless. Our souls are eternal and sentient because of the divine power bestowed upon us by God, who is situated in the heart of all living beings. The Bhagavatam confirms that God is the soul of our soul, the essence of all living beings. Shree Krishna explains that he is the source, sustainer, and ultimate destination of all life. All beings originate from him, are sustained by his energy, and those who attain liberation merge with him in his divine abode. This comprehensive perspective is supported by the Vedas, which describe God as the creator, sustainer, and ultimate reuniter of all living beings.
newest_commentary: In the Bhagavad Gita, Shree Krishna reveals his proximity to the soul, residing within and granting consciousness to it. Without him, the soul would be lifeless. Our souls are eternal and sentient due to God's divine power bestowed upon us. God is the soul of our soul and the essence of all living beings. Krishna explains his role as the source, sustainer, and ultimate destination of life. All beings originate from him, are sustained by his energy, and those who achieve liberation merge with him in his divine abode. This perspective aligns with the Vedas, which describe God as the creator, sustainer, and reuniter of all living beings.
